question: Question 12 Given the following syntax-directed translation rules: [latex] \text{Rule 1: } R \rightarrow AB \{ B.i = R.i - 1; A.i = B.i; R.i = A.i + 1; \} [/latex] [latex] \text{Rule 2: } P \rightarrow CD \{ P.i = C.i + D.i; D.i = C.i + 2; \} [/latex] [latex] \text{Rule 3: } Q \rightarrow EF \{ Q.i = E.i + F.i; \} [/latex] Which ONE is the CORRECT option among the following?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: Rule 1 is S-attributed and L-attributed;  Rule 2 is S-attributed and not L-attributed;  Rule 3 is neither S-attributed nor L-attributed.
options.B: Rule 1 is neither S-attributed nor L-attributed;  Rule 2 is S-attributed and L-attributed;  Rule 3 is S-attributed and L-attributed.
options.C: Rule 1 is neither S-attributed nor L-attributed;  Rule 2 is not S-attributed and is L-attributed;  Rule 3 is S-attributed and L-attributed.
options.D: Rule 1 is S-attributed and not L-attributed;  Rule 2 is not S-attributed and is L-attributed;  Rule 3 is S-attributed and L-attributed.

question: Question 19 Which of the following statements regarding Breadth First Search (BFS) and Depth First Search (DFS) on an undirected simple graph [latex]G [/latex] is/are TRUE?

options.B: Every non-tree edge of [latex]G [/latex] with respect to a DFS tree is a forward/back edge.
options.C: If [latex](u, v) [/latex] is a non-tree edge of [latex]G [/latex] with respect to a BFS tree, then the distances from the source vertex [latex]s [/latex] to [latex]u [/latex] and [latex]v [/latex] in the BFS tree are within [latex]\pm 1 [/latex] of each other.
options.D: Both BFS and DFS can be used to find the connected components of [latex]G [/latex].

question: Question 27 Let [latex]G [/latex] be an edge-weighted undirected graph with positive edge weights. Suppose a positive constant [latex]\alpha [/latex] is added to the weight of every edge. Which ONE of the following statements is TRUE about the minimum spanning trees (MSTs) and shortest paths (SPs) in [latex]G [/latex] before and after the edge weight update?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: Every MST remains an MST, and every SP remains an SP.
options.B: MSTs need not remain MSTs, and every SP remains an SP.
options.C: Every MST remains an MST, and SPs need not remain SPs.
options.D: MSTs need not remain MSTs, and SPs need not remain SPs.

\forall f, g \in \mathcal{F}, \, f \preceq g \quad \text{if and only if} \quad \forall x \in \{1, \dots, n\}, f(x) \leq g(x), \text{ where } 0 \leq 1.

question:
Question 34 Consider a system of linear equations [latex]P X = Q [/latex] where [latex]P \in \mathbb{R}^{3 \times 3} [/latex] and [latex]Q \in \mathbb{R}^{3 \times 1} [/latex].  
Suppose [latex]P [/latex] has an [latex]LU [/latex] decomposition, [latex]P = LU [/latex], where [latex] L = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ l_{21} & 1 & 0 \\ l_{31} & l_{32} & 1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad U = \begin{bmatrix} u_{11} & u_{12} & u_{13} \\ 0 & u_{22} & u_{23} \\ 0 & 0 & u_{33} \end{bmatrix} [/latex] Which of the following statement(s) is/are TRUE?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: The system [latex]P X = Q [/latex] can be solved by first solving [latex]L Y = Q [/latex] and then [latex]U X = Y [/latex].
options.B: If [latex]P [/latex] is invertible, then both [latex]L [/latex] and [latex]U [/latex] are invertible.
options.C: If [latex]P [/latex] is singular, then at least one of the diagonal elements of [latex]U [/latex] is zero.
options.D: If [latex]P [/latex] is symmetric, then both [latex]L [/latex] and [latex]U [/latex] are symmetric.

question: Question 35 Consider a stack data structure into which we can PUSH and POP records. Assume that each record pushed in the stack has a positive integer key and that all keys are distinct. We wish to augment the stack data structure with an [latex]O(1) [/latex] time MIN operation that returns a pointer to the record with the smallest key present in the stack 1) without deleting the corresponding record, and 2) without increasing the complexities of the standard stack operations. Which one or more of the following approach(es) can achieve it?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: Keep with every record in the stack, a pointer to the record with the smallest key below it.
options.B: Keep a pointer to the record with the smallest key in the stack.
options.C: Keep an auxiliary array in which the key values of the records in the stack are maintained in sorted order.
options.D: Keep a Min-Heap in which the key values of the records in the stack are maintained.

solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

question:
Question 38 [latex]P = \{P_1, P_2, P_3, P_4\} [/latex] consists of all active processes in an operating system.  
[latex]R = \{R_1, R_2, R_3, R_4\} [/latex] consists of single instances of distinct types of resources in the system. The resource allocation graph has the following assignment and claim edges. [latex]
\text{Assignment edges: } R_1 \to P_1,  R_2 \to P_2,  R_3 \to P_3,  R_4 \to P_4 
[/latex] (the assignment edge [latex]R_1 \to P_1[/latex] means resource [latex]R_1[/latex] is assigned to process [latex]P_1[/latex], and so on for others) [latex]
\text{Claim edges: } P_1 \to R_2, P_2 \to R_3, P_3 \to R_1, P_2 \to R_4, P_4 \to R_2
[/latex] (the claim edge [latex]P_1 \to R_2[/latex] means process [latex]P_1[/latex] is waiting for resource [latex]R_2[/latex], and so on for others) Which of the following statement(s) is/are CORRECT?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: Aborting [latex]P_1 [/latex] makes the system deadlock free.
options.B: Aborting [latex]P_3 [/latex] makes the system deadlock free.
options.C: Aborting [latex]P_2 [/latex] makes the system deadlock free.
options.D: Aborting [latex]P_1 [/latex] and [latex]P_4 [/latex] makes the system deadlock free.

question:
Question 41 Consider two grammars [latex]G1 [/latex] and [latex]G2 [/latex] with the production rules given below: [latex]
G1: S \to \text{if} E \text{ then } S \mid \text{if} E \text{ then } S \text{ else } S \mid a
[/latex] [latex]
E \to b
[/latex] [latex]
G2: S \to \text{if} E \text{ then } S \mid M
[/latex] [latex]
M \to \text{if} E \text{ then } M \text{ else } S \mid c
[/latex] [latex]
E \to b
[/latex] where [latex] if,then,else,a,b,c[/latex] are the terminals. Which of the following option(s) is/are CORRECT?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: [latex]G1 [/latex] is not LL(1) and [latex]G2 [/latex] is LL(1).
options.B: [latex]G1 [/latex] is LL(1) and [latex]G2 [/latex] is not LL(1).

question: Question 42 Let [latex]\Sigma = \{a, b, c\} [/latex]. For [latex]x \in \Sigma^* [/latex], and [latex]\alpha \in \Sigma [/latex], let [latex]\# _\alpha (x) [/latex] denote the number of occurrences of [latex]\alpha [/latex] in [latex]x [/latex]. Which one or more of the following option(s) define(s) regular language(s)?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.B: [latex]\{ a, b \}^* \cap \{ a^m b^n c^{m-n} \mid m \geq n \geq 0 \} [/latex]

question:
Question 44 Consider the following relational schema: [latex]
\text{Students} (\text{\underline{rollno: integer,} name: string, age: integer, cgpa: real})
[/latex] [latex]
\text{Courses} (\text{\underline{courseno: integer,} cname: string, credits: integer})
[/latex] [latex]
\text{Enrolled} (\text{ \underline{rollno: integer,} \underline{courseno: integer,} grade: string})
[/latex] Which of the following options is/are correct SQL query/queries to retrieve the names of the students enrolled in course number (i.e. courseno) 1470?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: SELECT S.name FROM Students S WHERE EXISTS (SELECT * FROM Enrolled E WHERE E.courseno = 1470 AND E.rollno = S.rollno)
options.B: SELECT S.name FROM Students S WHERE SIZEOF (SELECT * FROM Enrolled E WHERE E.courseno = 1470 AND E.rollno = S.rollno) > 0
options.C: SELECT S.name FROM Students S WHERE 0 < (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM Enrolled E WHERE E.courseno = 1470 AND E.rollno = S.rollno)
options.D: SELECT S.name FROM Students S NATURAL JOIN Enrolled E WHERE E.courseno = 1470

question: Question 54 A quadratic polynomial [latex](x - \alpha)(x - \beta)[/latex] over complex numbers is said to be square invariant if [latex](x - \alpha)(x - \beta) = (x - \alpha^2)(x - \beta^2)[/latex]. Suppose from the set of all square invariant quadratic polynomials we choose one at random. The probability that the roots of the chosen polynomial are equal is ______. (rounded off to one decimal place)

question:
Question 63 Which one of the following options is correct for the given data in the table? [latex] \begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Iteration} (i) & 0 & 1 & 2 & 3 \\
\hline
\text{Input} (I) & 20 & -4 & 10 & 15 \\
\hline
\text{Output} (X) & 20 & 16 & 26 & 41 \\
\hline
\text{Output} (Y) & 20 & -80 & -800 & -12000 \\
\hline
\end{array} [/latex]
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: [latex]X(i) = X(i - 1) + I(i);  \quad Y(i) = Y(i - 1) I(i);   \quad i > 0 [/latex]
options.B: [latex]X(i) = X(i - 1) I(i); \quad Y(i) = Y(i - 1) + I(i); \quad i > 0 [/latex]
options.C: [latex]X(i) = X(i - 1) I(i); \quad Y(i) = Y(i - 1) I(i); \quad i > 0 [/latex]
options.D: [latex]X(i) = X(i - 1) + I(i); \quad Y(i) = Y(i - 1) I(i ? 1); \quad i > 0 [/latex]

question: Question 65 The diagram below shows a river system consisting of 7 segments, marked P, Q, R, S, T, U, and V. It splits the land into 5 zones, marked Z1, Z2, Z3, Z4, and Z5.
